Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: One way a word enters a language is by:
Options: A. Borrowing it from another language, B. Cloning an existing word, C. Luck, D. Eliminating another word
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many new words are added to the Oxford English Dictionary each year? Options: A. 500, B. 1,000, C. 5,000, D. 10,000 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of the English language vocabulary comes directly from other languages? Options: A. A quarter, B. Nearly half, C. Three-quarters, D. Almost all Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the origin of the word "clone" in the English language? Options: A. Derived from Ancient Greek word for "plant", B. Derived from Ancient Greek word for "twig", C. Derived from Latin word for "cell", D. Derived from French word for "copy" Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a compound word in the English language? Options: A. Airport, B. Software, C. Internet, D. Villain Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the process called when a word comes to mean its opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse? Options: A. Word blending, B. Word clipping, C. Word shifting, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who coined the term "meme" in the 1970s? Options: A. Richard Dawkins, B. Charles Darwin, C. Stephen Hawking, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the term for words that describe themselves? Options: A. Autological, B. Analogical, C. Etymological, D. Lexical Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why do some new words become mainstream while others fall out of use or never catch on? Options: A. Because they are officially recognized by dictionaries, B. Because they are created by language academies, C. Because they hit the right combination of useful and catchy, D. Because they are used by scientists and companies Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do scientists often use classical languages in the English language? Options: A. To name new concepts, B. To describe complex ideas, C. To create compound words, D. To borrow words from other languages Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is an example of a word that has undergone a significant change in meaning over time? Options: A. Villain, B. Geek, C. Clone, D. All of the above Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists sometimes use ______ to name a new idea.
Options: A. An already-existing term, B. A synonym, C. Words from a classical language, D. Random phonetic sounds
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many new words are added to the Oxford English Dictionary each year? Options: A. 500, B. 1,000, C. 5,000, D. 10,000 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What percentage of the English language vocabulary comes directly from other languages? Options: A. A quarter, B. Nearly half, C. Three-quarters, D. Almost all Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the origin of the word "clone" in the English language? Options: A. Derived from Ancient Greek word for "plant", B. Derived from Ancient Greek word for "twig", C. Derived from Latin word for "cell", D. Derived from French word for "copy" Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is an example of a compound word in the English language? Options: A. Airport, B. Software, C. Internet, D. Villain Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the process called when a word comes to mean its opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse? Options: A. Word blending, B. Word clipping, C. Word shifting, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who coined the term "meme" in the 1970s? Options: A. Richard Dawkins, B. Charles Darwin, C. Stephen Hawking, D. Albert Einstein Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the term for words that describe themselves? Options: A. Autological, B. Analogical, C. Etymological, D. Lexical Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why do some new words become mainstream while others fall out of use or never catch on? Options: A. Because they are officially recognized by dictionaries, B. Because they are created by language academies, C. Because they hit the right combination of useful and catchy, D. Because they are used by scientists and companies Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do scientists often use classical languages in the English language? Options: A. To name new concepts, B. To describe complex ideas, C. To create compound words, D. To borrow words from other languages Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is an example of a word that has undergone a significant change in meaning over time? Options: A. Villain, B. Geek, C. Clone, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: How do scientists often use classical languages in the English language? Options: A. To name new concepts, B. To describe complex ideas, C. To create compound words, D. To borrow words from other languages.

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks how scientists sometimes name a new idea. Both questions are related to the use of classical languages in the English language, and the correct option in Question 9 (A. To name new concepts) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. Words from a classical language).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9.

part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

Correct Option: B

and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that

part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages

from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where in the world is cotton commonly grown?
Options: A. India, B. China, C. America, D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of t-shirts sold and bought globally each year? Options: A. 1 billion, B. 2 billion, C. 5 billion, D. 10 billion Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following countries is the world's biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts? Options: A. China, B. India, C. Bangladesh, D. Turkey Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many liters of water are needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 1,000 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 5,000 liters, D. 10,000 liters Correct Option: None
Question 4: What percentage of global carbon emissions is attributed to apparel production? Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the vivid coloring used in about 70% of textiles that can contain cancer-causing chemicals? Options: A. Azo dyes, B. Organic dyes, C. Synthetic dyes, D. Natural dyes Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which of the following is a suggested way to reduce the environmental impact of clothing consumption? Options: A. Buying more clothes, B. Washing clothes more frequently, C. Shopping secondhand, D. Using more energy-intensive washing machines Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many people are employed in the t-shirt industry in Bangladesh? Options: A. 1 million, B. 2 million, C. 4.5 million, D. 10 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the estimated number of garments produced globally each year? Options: A. 40 billion, B. 60 billion, C. 80 billion, D. 100 billion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the main reason for the dramatic shift in clothing consumption over the last 20 years? Options: A. Increased awareness of environmental issues, B. The trend of fast fashion driven by large corporations, C. Improved manufacturing technologies, D. Changes in consumer behavior Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ranking of the fashion industry in terms of pollution, compared to other industries? Options: A. First, B. Second, C. Third, D. Fourth Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the common locations where cotton is grown. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 2 asks about the world's biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, which is related to the cotton industry. However, this is not a direct match.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat similar, I would suggest Question 2. However, please note that this is not a direct match, and the generated MCQs do not adequately cover the topic of the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To produce the average t-shirt takes:
Options: A. 225 kg of cotton, B. Large amounts of pesticides, C. 2700 liters of water, D. C only, E. Both B and C
Correct Option: E

from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most

Correct Option: A

and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After t-shirts are made and shipped to high income countries, often the ____ footprint of the item increases drastically.
Options: A. Cadmium, B. Cotton, C. Carbon, D. Lead
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated number of t-shirts sold and bought globally each year? Options: A. 1 billion, B. 2 billion, C. 5 billion, D. 10 billion Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following countries is the world's biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts? Options: A. China, B. India, C. Bangladesh, D. Turkey Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many liters of water are needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 1,000 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 5,000 liters, D. 10,000 liters Correct Option: None
Question 4: What percentage of global carbon emissions is attributed to apparel production? Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the vivid coloring used in about 70% of textiles that can contain cancer-causing chemicals? Options: A. Azo dyes, B. Organic dyes, C. Synthetic dyes, D. Natural dyes Correct Option: None
Question 6: Which of the following is a suggested way to reduce the environmental impact of clothing consumption? Options: A. Buying more clothes, B. Washing clothes more frequently, C. Shopping secondhand, D. Using more energy-intensive washing machines Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many people are employed in the t-shirt industry in Bangladesh? Options: A. 1 million, B. 2 million, C. 4.5 million, D. 10 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the estimated number of garments produced globally each year? Options: A. 40 billion, B. 60 billion, C. 80 billion, D. 100 billion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the main reason for the dramatic shift in clothing consumption over the last 20 years? Options: A. Increased awareness of environmental issues, B. The trend of fast fashion driven by large corporations, C. Improved manufacturing technologies, D. Changes in consumer behavior Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ranking of the fashion industry in terms of pollution, compared to other industries? Options: A. First, B. Second, C. Third, D. Fourth Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you decreased the amount of laundry loads in your household to 100 less than the average, how much water would you save per year?
Options: A. 200 gallons, B. 400 gallons, C. 600 gallons, D. 800 gallons
Correct Option: B

Question 3: How many liters of water are needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 1,000 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 5,000 liters, D. 10,000 liters Correct Option: None
Question 4: What percentage of global carbon emissions is attributed to apparel production? Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: None

Question 6: Which of the following is a suggested way to reduce the environmental impact of clothing consumption? Options: A. Buying more clothes, B. Washing clothes more frequently, C. Shopping secondhand, D. Using more energy-intensive washing machines Correct Option: None
Question 7: How many people are employed in the t-shirt industry in Bangladesh? Options: A. 1 million, B. 2 million, C. 4.5 million, D. 10 million Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the estimated number of garments produced globally each year? Options: A. 40 billion, B. 60 billion, C. 80 billion, D. 100 billion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the main reason for the dramatic shift in clothing consumption over the last 20 years? Options: A. Increased awareness of environmental issues, B. The trend of fast fashion driven by large corporations, C. Improved manufacturing technologies, D. Changes in consumer behavior Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ranking of the fashion industry in terms of pollution, compared to other industries? Options: A. First, B. Second, C. Third, D. Fourth Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can try to find the one that is most similar.

Although the question intent is not the same, both MCQs are related to water usage. Therefore, I would say that Question 3 is the most similar generated MCQ, even though it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cupid makes people fall in love with each other:
Options: A. By pricking them with an arrow, B. By setting them up on blind dates, C. By casting a spell, D. Though his mother Venus, goddess of love
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Psyche compared to due to her exceptional physical perfection? Options: A. Venus, the goddess of war, B. Venus, the goddess of love, C. Athena, the goddess of wisdom, D. Artemis, the goddess of the hunt Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to the Oracle of Apollo, what was Psyche destined to marry on the rocky crag? Options: A. A kind and gentle god, B. A cruel and savage serpent-like winged evil, C. A mortal man, D. A mythical creature Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who helped Psyche by gently lifting her into the air and setting her down before a palace? Options: A. Zephyr, the East Wind, B. Zephyr, the West Wind, C. Cupid, the god of love, D. Apollo, the god of light Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the one question Psyche's husband told her she could never ask him? Options: A. What his favorite food was, B. What his name was, C. What his occupation was, D. Who he was Correct Option: None
Question 5: What did Psyche use to see her husband's true form, which ultimately led to him leaving her? Options: A. A candle, B. An oil lamp, C. A torch, D. The light of the full moon Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the name of the god who sent gods and humans lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows? Options: A. Apollo, B. Cupid, C. Ares, D. Dionysus Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the first task Venus assigned to Psyche in order for her to wed Cupid? Options: A. To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep, B. To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night, C. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box, D. To slay a dragon Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who helped Psyche complete her first task by sorting the seeds for her? Options: A. A group of fairies, B. An ant colony, C. A group of friendly humans, D. A magical creature Correct Option: None
Question 9: What did Psyche find in the box she was supposed to bring back to Venus, which ultimately led to her collapse? Options: A. A magical potion, B. A beautiful dress, C. Sleep, D. Beauty Correct Option: None
Question 10: What did Cupid give Psyche to make her immortal? Options: A. Ambrosia, the nectar of the gods, B. A magical elixir, C. A special potion, D. A divine blessing Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 6: What was the name of the god who sent gods and humans lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows? Options: A. Apollo, B. Cupid, C. Ares, D. Dionysus**

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks how Cupid makes people fall in love with each other. Although the generated MCQ does not directly ask about Cupid's method, it does ask about the god who sends gods and humans lusting after each other, which is a key aspect of Cupid's role in the story. The correct option, B. Cupid, is also consistent with the ground truth MCQ.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. But among the given options, Question 6 is the most similar.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Venus is jealous of Psyche because:
Options: A. Cupid falls in love with Psyche, B. Psyche is brave, C. Psyche drinks ambrosia, becoming immortal like a god, D. Psyche steals beauty from the underworld, E. Psyche is so beautiful she attracts her own worshippers, like a god
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Psyche compared to due to her exceptional physical perfection? Options: A. Venus, the goddess of war, B. Venus, the goddess of love, C. Athena, the goddess of wisdom, D. Artemis, the goddess of the hunt Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to the Oracle of Apollo, what was Psyche destined to marry on the rocky crag? Options: A. A kind and gentle god, B. A cruel and savage serpent-like winged evil, C. A mortal man, D. A mythical creature Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who helped Psyche by gently lifting her into the air and setting her down before a palace? Options: A. Zephyr, the East Wind, B. Zephyr, the West Wind, C. Cupid, the god of love, D. Apollo, the god of light Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the one question Psyche's husband told her she could never ask him? Options: A. What his favorite food was, B. What his name was, C. What his occupation was, D. Who he was Correct Option: None
Question 5: What did Psyche use to see her husband's true form, which ultimately led to him leaving her? Options: A. A candle, B. An oil lamp, C. A torch, D. The light of the full moon Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the name of the god who sent gods and humans lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows? Options: A. Apollo, B. Cupid, C. Ares, D. Dionysus Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the first task Venus assigned to Psyche in order for her to wed Cupid? Options: A. To bring her the fleece of the golden sheep, B. To sort a huge, messy pile of seeds in a single night, C. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box, D. To slay a dragon Correct Option: None
Question 8: Who helped Psyche complete her first task by sorting the seeds for her? Options: A. A group of fairies, B. An ant colony, C. A group of friendly humans, D. A magical creature Correct Option: None
Question 9: What did Psyche find in the box she was supposed to bring back to Venus, which ultimately led to her collapse? Options: A. A magical potion, B. A beautiful dress, C. Sleep, D. Beauty Correct Option: None
Question 10: What did Cupid give Psyche to make her immortal? Options: A. Ambrosia, the nectar of the gods, B. A magical elixir, C. A special potion, D. A divine blessing Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question and options are not identical, the content and intent are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks why Venus is jealous of Psyche, with the correct option being that Psyche is so beautiful she attracts her own worshippers, like a god. Question 1 asks who Psyche was compared to due to her exceptional physical perfection, with the correct answer being Venus, the goddess of love. 

Both questions relate to Psyche's beauty and its comparison to a goddess, which is the root of Venus's jealousy. Therefore, Question 1 is the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The voice Psyche hears:
Options: A. Is an emanation of her own courage, B. Is Cupid’s, C. Has different interpretations in different versions of the myth, D. Is Zephyr, the west wind, E. Is Venus
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened

of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Very slowly, B. With the help of some ants, C. With the help of a river god, D. So she can retrieve Proserpina’s beauty from the underworld, E. By striking a bargain with a dwarf named Rumpelstiltskin

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which statement below is a myth?
Options: A. The human brain is clearly divided into two parts, B. The left side of the brain controls logic, and the right controls creativity, C. The outer layer of the brain is called the cortex, D. Both a and b are myths
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the commonly-held myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence? Options: A. The brain has a right and left side., B. The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity., D. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the actual function of the left and right sides of the brain in terms of movement control? Options: A. The left side controls the motion of the left arm and leg., B. The right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg., C. The left side controls the motion of the right arm and leg., D. The right side controls the motion of the left arm and leg. Correct Option: None
Question 3: How does the brain process visual information from each eye? Options: A. Each eye sends information to the same side of the brain., B. Each eye sends information to the opposite side of the brain., C. Both left visual fields are sent to the left side of the brain., D. Both left visual fields are sent to the right side of the brain. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is one theory for why the brain has a left-right structure for certain functions? Options: A. It allows for more complex nervous systems., B. It gives a survival advantage of quicker reflexes., C. It allows for more creative problem-solving., D. It allows for more logical thinking. Correct Option: None
Question 5: Who are the two neurologists that examined patients with communication problems due to injuries and suggested that language is controlled by the left side of the brain? Options: A. Broca and Wernicke, B. Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, C. Robert Louis Stevenson and Charles Darwin, D. Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the result of examining patients who were missing a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated? Options: A. They showed only logical behaviors., B. They showed only creative behaviors., C. They showed a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative., D. They showed no behaviors at all. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the relationship between language and attention in terms of brain function? Options: A. Language is more localized to the right side and attention to the left., B. Language is more localized to the left side and attention to the right., C. Language and attention are equally distributed between both sides., D. Language and attention are not related to brain function. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the conclusion about the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity? Options: A. It is supported by scientific evidence., B. It is not supported by scientific evidence, but it is still a useful concept., C. It is not supported by scientific evidence, and it is not a useful concept., D. It is still a topic of debate among scientists. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the relationship between logic and creativity in problem-solving and art? Options: A. Logic and creativity are mutually exclusive., B. Logic and creativity are separate but equal., C. Logic and creativity are intertwined and necessary for each other., D. Logic and creativity are only necessary for certain tasks. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the overall conclusion about brain function and behavior? Options: A. The brain functions as two separate hemispheres., B. The brain functions as one unified whole., C. The brain functions as a combination of both separate hemispheres and a unified whole., D. The brain function is still not fully understood. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Question 1: What is the commonly-held myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence? 
Options: A. The brain has a right and left side., B. The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity., D. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world.

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the myth about the brain. The correct answer in the ground truth MCQ is "The left side of the brain controls logic, and the right controls creativity," which is option C in Question 1. Although the generated MCQ does not have a designated correct answer, option C matches the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The right side of the brain controls the movement of the:
Options: A. Right side arm and leg, B. Left side arm and leg, C. Both arms and legs, D. The eyes
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight., C. The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity., D. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world. Correct Option: None

Question 5: Who are the two neurologists that examined patients with communication problems due to injuries and suggested that language is controlled by the left side of the brain? Options: A. Broca and Wernicke, B. Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, C. Robert Louis Stevenson and Charles Darwin, D. Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the result of examining patients who were missing a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated? Options: A. They showed only logical behaviors., B. They showed only creative behaviors., C. They showed a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative., D. They showed no behaviors at all. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the relationship between language and attention in terms of brain function? Options: A. Language is more localized to the right side and attention to the left., B. Language is more localized to the left side and attention to the right., C. Language and attention are equally distributed between both sides., D. Language and attention are not related to brain function. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the conclusion about the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity? Options: A. It is supported by scientific evidence., B. It is not supported by scientific evidence, but it is still a useful concept., C. It is not supported by scientific evidence, and it is not a useful concept., D. It is still a topic of debate among scientists. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the relationship between logic and creativity in problem-solving and art? Options: A. Logic and creativity are mutually exclusive., B. Logic and creativity are separate but equal., C. Logic and creativity are intertwined and necessary for each other., D. Logic and creativity are only necessary for certain tasks. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the overall conclusion about brain function and behavior? Options: A. The brain functions as two separate hemispheres., B. The brain functions as one unified whole., C. The brain functions as a combination of both separate hemispheres and a unified whole., D. The brain function is still not fully understood. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When patients who had both hemispheres of their brains separated were tested, what was the result?
Options: A. they had no creativity, B. They had no logic, C. The patients showed both logical and creative behaviors, D. Patients lost their eyesight
Correct Option: C
